statement: F. Ber Patiotime limit per test3 secondsmemory limit per test512 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputPolycarp is a regular customer at the restaurant "Ber Patio". A customer can collect bonuses and partially cover expenses in the restaurant.Let's assume a customer currently hasbbonuses and she has to payrburles for a lunch. In this case the customer can use bonuses (1 bonus = 1 burle) to reduce the payment. She can cover at most half of the payment using bonuses. However, 1 bonus will be added to the customer's bonus balance per each 10 burles she paid.Formally:a customer can choose any numberxof bonuses to use ()),the customer's bonus balance is reduced byx,the customer paysr-xburles,the customer's bonus balance is increased by⌊(r-x) / 10⌋(i.e. integer division rounded down is used).Initially, there arebbonuses on Polycarp's account. You are given a number of days $n$ and an initial number of bonuses $b$. Each day, you have a receipt with a cost $a_i$ in burles. You can use bonuses to pay for your meals, with 1 bonus equaling 1 burle. You can use at most half of the cost of each meal in bonuses. For every 10 burles you pay, you get 1 bonus.

Find the minimum number of burles you need to spend over all $n$ days and determine how many bonuses to use each day to achieve this minimum. 

The sum of all receipts does not exceed $10^5$ burles.

You have a set of costs for  'n' days. You have a starting number of points. Each day, you can use points to reduce the cost, but you can only use up to half the cost in points. For every 10 burles paid, you get 1 point. Find the minimum total burles you need to pay and how many points to use each day.
